ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a much fuller understanding of pre-17th century music notation as well as the concept of music notation as an important technological development.

This course started as a fascinating journey through the most important stages in the development of Western musical notation, and ended with several guest lectures on various other notation-related topics, some in the Western tradition and some outside it. I learned a great deal about the fundamental assumptions and priorities that Western music notation embodies, and also about alternative methods of notation that question those assumptions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminars were fun and engaging, and I really enjoyed the readings. The assignments were informative and fairly given. I only wish the due dates were posted at the beginning of the semester - even so, we were given ample notice of any work with due dates.

The content of this course was consistently engaging, and well-presented by Professor Zayaruznaya and the assigned readings. Especially on the transcription assignments, I wish I had received more thorough feedback, since there were many small details of the various notation systems that we were assigned to work with that I wasn't totally confident about.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In general, I think this course was well-adapted to COVID restrictions. I do wish we had been able to sing through notation examples more often, but there isn't really a good way to do that over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, but make sure that you are truly interested in early music notation technologies if you do take this course as the subject matter is rather niche.
Yes! This was a really interesting course with a very comfortable, collegial, group-learning kind of atmosphere.

extras.title:
MUSI 546 01/MUSI 455 01
        A History of Music Notation/Histories of Music Notation
